awd_titl_txt: Detection of Gravitational Waves: Data Analysis, Detector Characterization, and Instrument Science for Advanced LIGO
awd_abstract_narration:
Data analysis and instrument science research for advanced gravitational-wave detectors will be carried out. Coherent searches for gravitational-wave bursts with networks of detectors will be developed and implemented. Special attention is given to intermediate-mass binary black hole mergers and to binary systems with highly eccentric orbits. Online burst searches, which enable joint gravitational-wave and electromagnetic observations, will be developed. Stochastic intermediate data will be generated for stochastic searches, such as those analyzing long duration transients. In instrument science, work on thermal adaptive mode-matching, devices for beam-jitter suppression, and improved wavefront sensing will be carried out. Looking further into the future, studies of cryogenic materials and devices, including silicon for test masses, will take place.

The UF LIGO group gives students and postdoctoral scientists the opportunity to develop scientific skills from a diverse set of disciplines spanning lasers and optics, electronics and feedback control systems, vacuum and cryogenics, computational methods, data analysis algorithm development, and large-scale detector commissioning and operation. The University of Florida LIGO group places high value on the education of undergraduate students and each year has involved undergraduates in research. In addition, the group has a strong tradition of mentoring students and postdocs in the UF LIGO laboratory; many of these students have gone on to further education and careers in gravitational wave science. These efforts will continue. This work will positively impact the national and international scientific infrastructure through UF LIGO direct participation in research and operations at the LIGO Observatories. Finally, the proposed research has impacts that go beyond gravitational wave science. High-power optical devices developed in this project have commercial applications to the laser and optics industries.

por.por_cntn:
The  goals of the project are to detect gravitational waves using the advanced LIGO detectors. Major activities include instrument science, gravitational-wave data analysis, and characterization of LIGO data. Instrument science includes devices and components for the input optics subsystem as well as heat transfer and cryogenic experiments for third-generation detectors. Data analysis includes development of the search algorithms, searches for gravitational wave signals, and methods for astrophysical interpretation of LIGO data.

The input optics contains electro-optic modulators  which generate radio-frequency  sidebands, used for length and alignment sensing within the interferometer. For advanced LIGO, the modulators operate reliably with the required noise performance at 180 W laser power. In addition, Faraday isolators are needed to prevent reflected light from returning to the laser and to extract signals for the control system. The IO team developed and installed in advanced LIGO a custom Faraday isolator that provides passive compensation of thermal lensing and thermal depolarization. Other work in instrument science included studies of radiative heat transfer, interferometer simulations, and the development of beam steering methods inside the vacuum chambers.

For data analysis, the University of Florida LIGO group  developed  the coherent WaveBurst pipeline. Coherent WaveBurst is the LIGO flagship pipeline to search for gravitational wave transients of unknown origin. In preparation for the first advanced LIGO operations, we performed a major upgrade of the pipeline. It does not require the astrophysical model of the signal and can detect unexpected signals. The pipeline is used  in an all-sky search, a baseline search in LIGO for transient gravitational wave signals. It also is the basis of an online search using data from the two LIGO interferometers.  The objective of the online search is to detect gravitational wave signals in real time and alert other observational instruments for electromagnetic followup. The coherent WaveBurst online analysis was run during the ER8 and O1 runs of advanced LIGO.  It detected the first gravitational wave signal GW150914, on September 14, 2015, within 3 minutes after the event. Due to increased pipeline performance, we were able to establish the significance of this event as a 4.6 standard deviation observation. The coherent WaveBurst search results were published in the paper reporting the observation of gravitational waves from the inspiral and coalescence of two black holes.

In addition, a sensitivity study was conducted for r-mode gravitational wave signals from new-born neutron stars.  A paper outlining the nature of the targeted sources and a method to constrain the nuclear equation of state has been published.  Using a combination of available pattern recognition tools for identifying statistically significant structure in two-dimensional maps, we developed a sensitivity study, for signals on the timescale of minutes to days, that might result from new-born neutron stars.  A second paper considering Machine Learning Algorithms for identifying signals has been submitted for publication.
